stem: A 62-year-old patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with altered mental status, dehydration, and rapid, deep breathing. Initial lab results indicate hyperglycemia (serum glucose 650 mg/dL), ketonuria, and an arterial pH of 7.25. The patient is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Place the following interventions in order of priority.

rationale.correct: The priority in DKA management is to address the life-threatening issues first. Initial actions should focus on fluid resuscitation to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, followed by insulin administration to address hyperglycemia and ketogenesis. Potassium replacement is crucial to prevent hypokalemia as insulin drives potassium into cells. Finally, identifying and treating the underlying cause (e.g., infection) addresses the trigger for DKA. Delaying any of these steps can lead to worsening acidosis, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially fatal outcomes.
rationale.incorrect: Administering potassium before initiating fluid resuscitation can be harmful if the patient is already hyperkalemic due to dehydration and acidosis. Addressing the underlying cause should follow initial stabilization. Administering insulin before addressing fluid deficit can worsen hypokalemia and shock. Providing 0.45% normal saline is a maintenance fluid, not a resuscitation fluid for severe dehydration. Waiting to correct electrolytes until after insulin is administered can lead to dangerous hypokalemia.
clinicalPearls: Always check potassium levels before initiating insulin therapy in DKA patients.
Fluid resuscitation is paramount in DKA to improve perfusion and kidney function.
Monitor ABGs closely to assess the effectiveness of treatment and adjust interventions accordingly.

questionTrap.trap: Students often prioritize insulin administration due to the high glucose level, overlooking the importance of initial fluid resuscitation and electrolyte balance.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the 'ABCs' and prioritize interventions that address immediate threats to life, such as dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, before addressing the hyperglycemia itself.

mnemonic.title: DKA FIRST
mnemonic.expansion: Fluids, Insulin, Replace Electrolytes, Search for cause, Transition to subcutaneous insulin

reviewUnits.title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis Management
reviewUnits.content: Review the steps for managing DKA, including fluid resuscitation, insulin administration, electrolyte replacement, and identifying the underlying cause.

itemContext.sbar:
0700: RN to MD: Jane Doe, 62yo female, admitted with DKA. Blood glucose 650 mg/dL, pH 7.25. Ketonuria present. Altered mental status. Vitals: HR 120, BP 90/60, RR 32 and deep, Temp 98.8°F. 
0715: Patient received 1L NS bolus per protocol. Repeat glucose 600 mg/dL, pH 7.28. Initiating insulin drip per protocol at 0.1 unit/kg/hr. Potassium is 3.2 mEq/L. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and blood glucose every hour is ongoing. 
0730: Patient remains lethargic but responsive to verbal stimuli. Respiratory rate has slightly decreased to 28. Monitoring electrolytes and glucose closely. Patient is reporting nausea.
0745: Implementing interventions per DKA protocol.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content:
0600: Patient arrived via EMS, exhibiting Kussmaul respirations and altered mental status. Noted to be severely dehydrated. History of Type 2 DM. 
0630: Placed on cardiac monitor, IV access obtained. Initial labs drawn. Patient remains lethargic.
0700: See SBAR note.

tabs.title: Lab Diagnostics
tabs.content: Na 132 mEq/L | K 3.2 mEq/L | Cl 98 mEq/L | HCO3 10 mEq/L | BUN 35 mg/dL | Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL | Glucose 650 mg/dL | pH 7.25 | pCO2 28 mmHg | pO2 95 mmHg | Anion Gap 24 | Urine Ketones Positive

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: HR 120 bpm | BP 90/60 mmHg | RR 32 breaths/min (deep) | Temp 98.8°F (37.1°C) | SpO2 96% on room air | GCS 12 (E3, V4, M5)

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Insulin Regular IV drip (0.1 unit/kg/hr) | 0.9% Normal Saline 1L bolus (completed) | Metoprolol 25mg PO BID (scheduled, hold per MD order due to hypotension) | Multivitamin Daily PO (scheduled)

options.text: Initiate intravenous fluid resuscitation with 0.9% normal saline.
Identify and treat the underlying cause of DKA.

a.reason: This is the correct first step in managing DKA due to the patient's dehydration.

b.reason: While insulin is important, it is not the first step. Fluid resuscitation should come first to address dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

c.reason: Potassium replacement is important, but it should be done after fluid resuscitation and with careful monitoring, as insulin administration can further decrease potassium levels.

d.reason: Identifying and treating the underlying cause is important, but it is not the immediate priority. Stabilizing the patient with fluids and insulin is the first step.
